Rupert Murdoch's gang of mind rapists on Fox.
 
 Rush Limbaugh.
 
 The thousands of others who daily pollute the publicly-owned airwaves and rape the minds of unsuspecting Americans who obligingly bend over and get nailed over and over again.
 
America lets radio and TV broadcasters use public airwaves worth more than half a trillion dollars for free. In return, we require that broadcasters serve the public interest: devoting at least some airtime for worthy programs that inform voters, support local arts and culture and educate our children - in other words, that aspire to something beyond just minimizing costs and maximizing revenue.
 
 Using the public airwaves is a privilege - a lucrative one - not a right, and I fear the F.C.C. has not done enough to stand up for the public interest. Our policies should reward broadcasters that honor their pledge to serve that interest and penalize those that don't.
 
 The F.C.C. already has powerful leverage to hold broadcasters to their end of the bargain. Every eight years, broadcasters must prove that they have served the public interest in order to get license renewal. If they can't, the license goes to someone else who will. It's a tough but fair system - if the commission does its job.
 
 http://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/02/opinion/02copps.html
 
 Is the public being served by this endless, repetitious rape?

Should local broadcasters be accountable to the communities they serve?
 
 For example:
 
EXCLUSIVE... 911 Calls in North Dakota Town Reveal Dangers of Media Consolidation
 January 25, 2007]
 Five years ago this week a train derailed in Minot, North Dakota leaking thousands of gallons of toxic chemicals into the air. One person died and hundreds were treated for immediate health problems. The city's six non-religious commercial radio stations-all owned by Clear Channel-never aired warnings for local residents....
 
 Two hundred forty thousand gallons of anhydrous ammonia leaked out of the train producing a vapor plume that floated over the town. Limited exposure burns the eyes, the skin, and the lungs. Larger doses can shut down the human respiratory system. The chemical leak in Minot, North Dakota ended up killing one person. Approximately 330 were treated for immediate health problems and more than 1,000 people needed medical care for recurring illnesses in the next month. But questions remain to this day over how the crisis was handled and the role played by media consolidation.
 
 The radio giant Clear Channel owned all six commercial stations in Minot, North Dakota. None of them broke into regular programming to provide emergency information to the city's residents. After the town's Emergency Alert System failed, local officials tried to call the stations-but no one answered. The stations continued to play music piped in from out of state.
 
 EXCLUSIVE... 911 Calls in North Dakota Town Reveal Dangers of Media Consolidation
 
 So, put that into your Kool-Aid filled pipe and smoke it.

I am surprised this was't pointed out earlier. The FCC has no ability to mandate the content of material sent over the operators granted frequency. This is a little misleading in that one may assume the operator therefore can transmit whatever it wants. It can, as long as it operates its station in the "public interest, convenience and necessity." It is required to actively determine what programming will satisfy this requirement and must adapt as those factors change.
 
 The FCC gives the operator the freedom to determine what programming best serves the community. Any XXXXX should be able to understand that creating programming that caters to a specific political ideology and is substantially opinion based is not operating in the "public interest, convenience and necessity." Even if the 80 - 100% right wing programming was news and not commentary it would still not be in compliance as the public is comprised of non-Republicans and Liberals. Shocking, I know. A few stations might be able to get away with it based on thier demographics, but not many.
 
 Being financially viable is the problem of the radio station not the government. If a radio station can't figure out how to be profitable within the terms of the agreement, bummer, sucks to be them. Someone else will. In America we call that capitalism. Congrats to Fox. Instead of whining about having to comply with the terms they agreed to, why not work that media magic on creating programming that conforms to the license requirements. 
 
 What your crying about is government thinking about performing it's function. Something it has been reluctant to do the past 20 - 30 years. The reason that in order to make up for it's dismal performance it is considering taking drastic steps that will cost radio operators to spend money they have become used to keeping and correct a problem that should never have been allowed to become it it now is.
 
 So we all understand this has nothing to do with the 1st Amendment nor profitability of programming. It has to do with radio stations operating in compliance with the law. If they can prove that there is no benefit to programming offering different points of view then make it all one sided and run with it. Maybe they play 2 hours of PSA's or give time to local charity organizations. Compliance doesn't require liberal radio and operators know this, but they want to maintain profits so put a BS spin on it and you BAA BAA sheep sound off like you've got a pair because you choose to let someone else think for you.

Interesting spin but does the law pass 1st Amendment muster? It only takes one judge and poof gone. 

 
 The FCC is pretty much hands off, which is nice but problems like this pop up as a result. The evidence to support programming is collected by the operator and then is reviewed by the FCC. The operator is in violation of law, not just contractual obligation regarding what it airs. The wording nor the remedies available to the FCC don't prohibit the operator from expressing it's right to free speech, which in turn doesn't guarantee the right to say whatever whenever. The operator is granted a conditional use license and given almost complete discretion with regards to how it complies with the public interest, convenience and necessity clause. 
 
 Again that doesn't necessarily mean opposing view at prime time or becoming C-Span for the drive home. So I would be surprised if a judged ruled against it without there being some special circumstances and as good as they may be I don't see EIB or Fox openly fighting the FCC, quietly yes.

 <Flush<
 
 Republicans Better Educated
 
 Republicans in the general public tend to be better educated than Democrats. In the 1994-2002 General Social Surveys (GSS), Republicans have over 6/10ths of a year more education on average than Democrats. Republicans also have a higher final mean educational degree. Further, Republicans scored better than Democrats on two word tests in the GSS--a short vocabulary test and a modified analogies test.
 
 If one breaks down the data by party affiliation and political orientation, the most highly educated group is conservative Republicans, who also score highest on the vocabulary and analogical reasoning tests. Liberal Democrats score only insignificantly lower than conservative Republicans. The least educated subgroups are moderate and conservative Democrats, who also score at the bottom (or very near the bottom) on vocabulary and analogy tests. - Prof. Jim Lindgren, law professor at Northwestern University and director of the Demography of Diversity Project

 Conservatives and Christians Give More to Charities, ABC says
 
 As Doug explores in his post below, people of faith give far more to charities than non-religious people, and conservatives give more to the poor than do liberals. That's the finding of a study by author Arthur Brooks and the conclusion trumpeted by a John Stossel report on ABC this week. 
 The report says: 
 "The single biggest predictor of whether someone will be charitable is his or her religious participation. Religious people are more likely to give to charity, and when they give, they give more money: four times as much. And Arthur Brooks told me that giving goes beyond their own religious organization: "Actually, the truth is that they're giving to more than their churches," he says. "The religious Americans are more likely to give to every kind of cause and charity, including explicitly non-religious charities."
 Christian conviction and conservative ideology increases the likelihood that an individual will give to charities-and not just to their churches, but to a variety of religious and secular causes. 
 As Christians, we give out of obligation-Scripture tells us to help the poor-but even more out of gratitude to God for his goodness. 
 
 Liberals who see care for the poor as a government responsibility, give far less as individuals. At the same time, they describe conservatives as non-caring, and Christians as exclusionary and hypocritical. This could not be further from the truth, and these findings document it. 
 
 Stones Cry Out: Conservatives and Christians Give More to Charities, ABC says

 A major university where people are more intelligent? Have you ever watched the documentary Indoctrinate U? (I'm sure you have since you are so much more intelligent than the rest of us poor schmoes)
 
 Know what it pointed out?
 
 95% of all professors at major universities considered themselves "liberal" or "democrat" or both. In conclusive studies, upper echelons of the administrative system were shown to give preference to professors who were presumed to share the administrations social preferences. Those who were considered "conservative" or "republican" were often shown to receive less support if not openly discriminated against in regards to tenure and status. Hence: a vicious circle. Left leaning professors were more likely to receive promotions into upper administration! (Where they then give favoritism to the "smart ones" and shuffle the "dumb consevatives" to menial roles.)
